messageBody:
Let me ask a far less sophisticated question: is the chart
revised_with_ipa.png good enough as it is to get beginning QS users
from anywhere in the world and who know no more about the IPA than a 5
minute read on wikipeda to begin writing comfortably? And is it good
enough to start generating examples of each letter in each of our
respective accents, even those of us who our going to interpret the
IPA symbols with the afore mentioned 5 minute wikipeada read? To my
untrained eye it seems good enough for this already except that It and
Eat may have a typo in being reversed and Yo-yo may have a typo maybe
intending the palatal approximant j instead. But do we need to add
other IPA indicators under some letters first? Is there anyone
glancing at the chart that says "whoa, that's not what I thought"?
If we can pop out something nice for beginners our conversation will
have already produced a nice useful artifact.


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
> Paul Tremblay scripsit:
>
> > Thanks for the response. I'm honestly not sure what you mean "is that
> > there is no precise sound of any vowel phoneme in English." Such
> > confusion is why I am glad we are discussing the issue. Here's the
> > problem I am having. If you take the traditional orthograhy letter
"o,"
> > there is certainly no one way to map this sound to IPA. There is
> > probably 5 or 6. That is the problem with traditional orthography.
>
> Your trouble stems from the fact that phonemes cannot be identified
> either with sounds or with written letters, but constitute a third,
> separate level.
>
> For example, the *sounds* of "f" and "v" have been present in English
> since the earliest times. However, originally they were both written
> with the letter "f", since it was entirely predictable which sound
> to use when. The voiceless f-sound was used at the beginning of a
> word, as in "fann", or next to an unvoiced consonant, as in "aefter".
> Elsewhere, the voiced v-sound was used, as in "seofon" and "heofon".
> (Never mind the funky vowels for now, just look at the consonants.)
> We can say that there were two sounds [f] and [v], but only one phoneme,
> conventionally notated /f/.
>
> After the Norman Conquest, a huge number of new words were introduced
> into English from French and Latin, putting v-sounds in places where
> English-speakers were not accustomed to say them. As a result,
> the existing letter "u" (which had a variant shape "v" used at the
> beginnings of words) came to be used instead of "f" in these words,
> giving us "seuen" and "heauen" as well as new words like "van"
> (short for "carouan"), a minimal pair with the older "fan". At this
> point we can say that there are two phonemes /f/ and /v/, though /v/
> does not have a spelling of its own.
>
> Eventually, the u/v confusion was sorted out, using the u-shape for the
> vowel, the v-shape for the consonant, giving us the modern spellings
> "fan", "seven", "heaven", "caravan", and "van".
>
> --
> John Cowan http://www.ccil.org/~cowan <cowan@...>
> You tollerday donsk? N. You tolkatiff scowegian? Nn.
> You spigotty anglease? Nnn. You phonio saxo? Nnnn.
> Clear all so! `Tis a Jute.... (Finnegans Wake 16.5)
>
